sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Afghanistan is a landlocked country located at the crossroads of Central and South Asia, known for its rugged terrain and rich cultural heritage.

sections.title: Capital City
sections.content: Kabul is the capital and largest city of Afghanistan, serving as its political and economic center.

sections.title: Currency
sections.content: The official currency is the Afghan afghani (AFN).

sections.title: Language
sections.content: The main languages spoken are Dari and Pashto, both of which are official languages.

sections.title: Traditional Food
sections.content: Popular dishes include Kabuli pulao, mantu (dumplings), and kebabs, often served with naan bread.

sections.title: Geography
sections.content: Afghanistan features mountainous regions like the Hindu Kush, deserts, and fertile valleys, with a continental climate.

sections.title: Culture
sections.content: Afghan culture is deeply rooted in poetry, music, and hospitality, with strong tribal and family traditions.

sections.title: Tourism
sections.content: While tourism is limited due to security concerns, historical sites like the Buddhas of Bamiyan and Herat Citadel are notable.

sections.title: Fun Fact
sections.content: Afghanistan is one of the few countries where Buzkashi, a traditional horseback sport involving a goat carcass, is played competitively.

history.event: Early civilizations emerged in the region, including settlements linked to the Indus Valley and Bactria–Margiana Archaeological Complex.
Alexander the Great conquered the region after defeating the Achaemenid Empire, introducing Hellenistic culture.
The Kushan Empire ruled much of Afghanistan, becoming a center for Buddhism, trade, and Silk Road exchange.
Islam spread into the region, gradually becoming the dominant religion and reshaping Afghan society and governance.
Genghis Khan and the Mongol Empire devastated major cities, causing large-scale destruction and population decline.
Babur captured Kabul and later founded the Mughal Empire, linking Afghanistan to South Asian imperial history.
Ahmad Shah Durrani founded the Durrani Empire, widely regarded as the birth of the modern Afghan state.
Afghanistan became a battleground during the Anglo-Afghan Wars as Britain attempted to control the region.
Afghanistan gained full independence following the Third Anglo-Afghan War.
King Zahir Shah ruled for 40 years, overseeing modernization, neutrality, and relative stability.
The monarchy was abolished in a coup, and Afghanistan was declared a republic.
The Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan, leading to a decade-long war and massive displacement.
The Taliban captured Kabul and established the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan.
A US-led coalition invaded Afghanistan after the September 11 attacks, overthrowing the Taliban government.
Afghanistan adopted a new constitution and held its first democratic presidential election.
The Taliban regained control following the withdrawal of international forces.
